0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Carcinoma of prostate, Advanced (palliative treatment): one 50-mg implant inserted SUBQ for 12 months

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• not indicated for use in pediatric patients (Vantas(R))
  • Central precocious puberty: one 50-mg implant inserted SUBQ every 12 months (Supprelin(R) LA)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Carcinoma of prostate, Advanced (palliative treatment)
  • Central precocious puberty

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), GnRH agonist analogs, or any component of the product
  • pregnancy; may cause fetal harm and spontaneous abortion

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- increased risk of myocardial infarction, sudden cardiac death, and stroke have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- androgen deprivation may prolong QT interval, evaluate benefit/risk of use in patients with congenital long QT syndrome, congenital heart failure, frequent electrolyte abnormalities, and concomitant QT-prolonging drugs; monitoring recommended
  • Endocrine or Metabolic:
  • -- hyperglycemia and new onset or worsening of glycemic control in diabetes mellitus has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- transient increase in testosterone during the first week of therapy may result in exacerbation symptoms or onset of new symptoms (eg, bone pain, neuropathy, hematuria, ureteral/bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Other:
  • -- anaphylaxis has been reported
  • -- spontaneous extrusion of implant has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- ureteral obstruction and spinal cord compression, has been reported; monitoring recommended in patients with metastatic vertebral lesions or urinary tract obstruction, particularly during first few weeks of treatment

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Histrelin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Implant site reaction (5.8% to 51.1%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Gynecomastia (4.1%), Hot sweats (65.5%)
  • Reproductive:Amenorrhea, Erectile dysfunction
  • Other:Fatigue (9.9%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Pituitary apoplexy
  • Hepatic:Injury of liver (Severe)
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Renal:Renal impairment (Mild) (4.7%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Histrelin acetate is a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonist that inhibits gonadotropin secretion. It increases levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) upon initiation of treatment but decreases at continuous administration of the drug.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic; C-terminal dealkylation and hydrolysis
  • Metabolites: peptide fragments

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • open implant vial just prior to insertion; do not bend or pinch the implant
  • remove the old implant at the time of administration of the new implant
  • under anesthesia, insert in the inner aspect of the upper arm halfway between the shoulder and the elbow and in the crease between the biceps and triceps

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• advanced prostate cancer: serum testosterone and PSA levels, periodically; for evidence of therapeutic response
  • central precocious puberty: luteinizing hormone, follicle stimulating hormone, and estradiol or testosterone levels at 1 month after insertion and then every 6 months thereafter, and height and bone age, every 6 to 12 months; for evidence of therapeutic response
  • blood glucose and/or HbA1c levels, periodically
  • electrolytes; periodically during treatment
  • spinal cord compression and ureteral obstruction; in at risk patients
  • signs and symptoms of cardiovascular disease
  • ECG; periodically during treatment

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
HISTRELIN
OVERDOSE: No information available. ADVERSE EFFECTS: FREQUENT - hot flashes and fatigue, as well as, bruising and pain/soreness/tenderness at the site of insertion. INFREQUENT - erythema and swelling at the insertion site, weight gain, erectile dysfunction, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, decreased libido, insomnia, constipation, headache and mild renal impairment.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
HISTRELIN
Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. There is no antidote available.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
HISTRELIN
TOXICITY: A specific toxic dose has not been established. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: The recommended dose is one implant inserted subcutaneously in the inner aspect of the upper arm for 12 months.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid wetting the arm with the implant for 24 hours and refrain from heavy lifting or strenuous exertion of the arm with the implant for 7 days after implant insertion.
  • Instruct patient on proper handling of dressing and any follow up regarding stitches, if appropriate.
  • Vantas(TM) implant may cause gynecomastia, hot sweats, nausea, vomiting, headache, insomnia, amenorrhea, erectile dysfunction, or fatigue.
  • Supprelin(R) LA implant may cause pain, swelling, or redness in or around the incision site.
  • Instruct patients to report new or worsening bone pain, weakness or numbness in legs, hematuria, or dysuria.
  • Advise caregiver that the child may experience initial new-onset or worsening of puberty symptoms (eg; light vaginal bleeding and breast enlargement in girls) with Supprelin(R) LA therapy, but that symptoms should resolve within 4 weeks.
